Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolutionary lability and adaptive plasticity in physiological and molecular mechanisms of behavior
Award.AbstractNarration: Genes shape how sensitive individuals are to environmental conditions during development, and this environmental sensitivity influences the behaviors produced in adulthood. This project seeks to understand how genes and developmental conditions together influence the brain, and how that alters social behaviors. The planned research takes advantage of extensive information on genetic and environmental influences on behavior of guppies, small fish that have evolved numerous behavioral responses to predators. Guppies that experience high and low levels of predation in the wild will be raised in laboratory conditions with and without predator exposure during development. Genetic and molecular experiments will link the patterns of gene expression in different brain regions to neural activity patterns and the resulting social behaviors. Results will demonstrate the extent to which similar behavioral traits (increased sociality in fish from high-predation sites and in fish exposed to predators) rely on the same gene expression changes and brain activity patterns, or whether similar behaviors may emerge from a variety of neural mechanisms. These findings will also reveal how sensitivity to environmental conditions shapes evolution of behavior. Developing this novel experimental approach will provide a model for other researchers seeking to understand the impacts of gene expression differences on behavior. The PIs will incorporate this research into undergraduate courses and will train graduate students via annual workshops on analysis of gene expression data. The simplicity and availability of guppies also make them amenable to enriching K-12 curricula in evolution and behavior, through development of a guppy module for for the Understanding Evolution resources for teaching evolution (http://evolution.berkeley.edu/). This project will allow the Colorado State University researchers to extend an ongoing program in which lab personnel work with middle school classes to design and implement behavioral experiments using guppies to reach a larger group of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.  The scientific goal of this project was to determine how organisms respond to changes in their environment and evaluate the consequences of those responses.  We found that organisms respond in diverse ways to changes in their environment:  the activity of their genes changes, their development changes, and their behavior changes.  Some of these changes are adaptive?that is, they make the organisms better suited to survive and reproduce in the changed environment; however, some changes are not adaptive. In particular, exposure to a novel environment (one that the species has not previously experienced in its evolutionary history) is likely to produce changes that do not help the organism survive or reproduce and might actually hinder them.

Broader Impacts. Our research uncovers the fundamental causes and consequences of diversity in development and behavior among individuals of the same species. This kind of diversity is the raw material for the evolution of all organisms that have ever existed on earth, including humans. Therefore, we cannot fully understand the natural world, or ourselves, without understanding the factors that shape this diversity. The project also supported training and professional development for many early-career researchers including undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral research fellows. Most of the early-career scientists supported by this project were women and/or members of other groups that are underrepresented in the scientific workforce.

Outcomes. To date, this project has resulted in 13 peer-reviewed publications, and additional manuscripts will be submitted for publication soon. The research was also presented at scientific conferences and in many public lectures at universities and other venues. Several of our publications and presentations reported that organisms often respond non-adaptively to environmental change (Ghalambor et al. 2015; Hoke et al. 2018; Fischer et al. 2021). Others showed that organisms often shift their development and behavior in response to different social interactions they experience while they are young (Lange et al. 2021a; Lange et al. 2021b), or to social environments they experience as adults (Daniel et al. 2019a; Daniel et al. 2019b; Daniel et al. 2020). We also reported strong evidence Ritalin exposure in male fish can change the behavior of their offspring and great-grandoffspring which were not themselves exposed to Ritalin (De Serrano et al. 2021).  We also wrote papers that reviewed and synthesized existing literature on the causes of genetic diversity in response to environmental change (Saltz et al. 2018); the effects time scale on the relationship between brain gene function and behavior (Rittschof and Hughes 2018), and on the effects of gene function on the evolution of patterns of development and aging (Hughes and Leips 2017). Undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows supported by this award have successfully completed bachelors and doctoral degrees and have transitioned to more advanced career stages.
